verses.verse: (Num. 20:16, 17) “Let me pass through your land. We will not turn aside into fields or vineyards; we will not drink water from wells. We will go by the King’s Highway until we have passed through your territory.”

(Deut. 29:7) But Sihon would not allow Israel to pass through his territory. So Sihon gathered all his people together and went out against Israel in the wilderness, (Deut. 2:32; Judg. 11:20) and he came to Jahaz and fought against Israel.

Then (Deut. 2:33; Josh. 12:1; Neh. 9:22; Ps. 135:10; 136:19; Amos 2:9) Israel defeated him with the edge of the sword, and took possession of his land from the Arnon to the Jabbok, as far as the people of Ammon; for the border of the people of Ammon was fortified.
So Israel took all these cities, and Israel (Amos 2:10) dwelt in all the cities of the Amorites, in Heshbon and in all its villages.
For Heshbon was the city of Sihon king of the Amorites, who had fought against the former king of Moab, and had taken all his land from his hand as far as the Arnon.
Therefore those who speak in proverbs say: “Come to Heshbon, let it be built; Let the city of Sihon be repaired.
“For (Jer. 48:45, 46) fire went out from Heshbon, A flame from the city of Sihon; It consumed (Deut. 2:9, 18; Is. 15:1) Ar of Moab, The lords of the (Num. 22:41; 33:52) heights of the Arnon.

Woe to you, (Jer. 48:46) Moab! You have perished, O people of (Judg. 11:24; 1 Kin. 11:33; 2 Kin. 23:13) Chemosh! He has given his (Is. 15:2, 5) sons as fugitives, And his (Is. 16:2) daughters into captivity, To Sihon king of the Amorites.
“But we have shot at them; Heshbon has perished (Num. 32:3, 34; Jer. 48:18, 22) as far as Dibon. Then we laid waste as far as Nophah, Which reaches to (Is. 15:2) Medeba.”
Thus Israel dwelt in the land of the Amorites.
Then Moses sent to spy out (Num. 32:1, 3, 35; Jer. 48:32) Jazer; and they took its villages and drove out the Amorites who were there.
(King Og Defeated) (Deut. 29:7) And they turned and went up by the way to (Deut. 3:1) Bashan. So Og king of Bashan went out against them, he and all his people, to battle (Josh. 13:12) at Edrei.

Then the LORD said to Moses, (Deut. 3:2) “Do not fear him, for I have delivered him into your hand, with all his people and his land; and (Num. 21:24; Ps. 135:10; 136:20) you shall do to him as you did to Sihon king of the Amorites, who dwelt at Heshbon.”
(Deut. 3:3, 4; 29:7; Josh. 13:12) So they defeated him, his sons, and all his people, until there was no survivor left him; and they took possession of his land.
(Balak Sends for Balaam) Then (Num. 33:48, 49) the children of Israel moved, and camped in the plains of Moab on the side of the Jordan across from Jericho.
Now (Josh. 24:9; Judg. 11:25; Mic. 6:5; Rev. 2:14) Balak the son of Zippor saw all that Israel had done to the Amorites.
And (Ex. 15:15) Moab was exceedingly afraid of the people because they were many, and Moab was sick with dread because of the children of Israel.

So Moab said to (Num. 25:15-18; 31:1-3; Josh. 13:21) the elders of Midian, “Now this company will lick up everything around us, as an ox licks up the grass of the field.” And Balak the son of Zippor was king of the Moabites at that time.

Then (Num. 31:8, 16; Deut. 23:4; Josh. 13:22; 24:9; Neh. 13:1, 2; Mic. 6:5; 2 Pet. 2:15; Jude 11; Rev. 2:14) he sent messengers to Balaam the son of Beor at (Deut. 23:4) Pethor, which is near the River in the land of the sons of his people, to call him, saying: “Look, a people has come from Egypt. See, they cover the face of the earth, and are settling next to me!

(Num. 22:17; 23:7, 8) Therefore please come at once, (Num. 22:12; 24:9) curse this people for me, for they are too mighty for me. Perhaps I shall be able to defeat them and drive them out of the land, for I know that he whom you bless is blessed, and he whom you curse is cursed.”
So the elders of Moab and the elders of Midian departed with the (1 Sam. 9:7, 8) diviner’s fee in their hand, and they came to Balaam and spoke to him the words of Balak.
And he said to them, (Num. 22:19) “Lodge here tonight, and I will bring back word to you, as the LORD speaks to me.” So the princes of Moab stayed with Balaam.
(Gen. 20:3) Then God came to Balaam and said, “Who are these men with you?”
So Balaam said to God, “Balak the son of Zippor, king of Moab, has sent to me, saying,
‘Look, a people has come out of Egypt, and they cover the face of the earth. Come now, curse them for me; perhaps I shall be able to overpower them and drive them out.’ ”
And God said to Balaam, “You shall not go with them; you shall not curse the people, for (Num. 23:20; (Rom. 11:28)) they are blessed.”
So Balaam rose in the morning and said to the princes of Balak, “Go back to your land, for the LORD has refused to give me permission to go with you.”
And the princes of Moab rose and went to Balak, and said, “Balaam refuses to come with us.”
Then Balak again sent princes, more numerous and more honorable than they.
And they came to Balaam and said to him, “Thus says Balak the son of Zippor: ‘Please let nothing hinder you from coming to me;
for I will certainly (Num. 24:11) honor you greatly, and I will do whatever you say to me. (Num. 22:6) Therefore please come, curse this people for me.’ ”

Then Balaam answered and said to the servants of Balak, (Num. 22:38; 24:13) “Though Balak were to give me his house full of silver and gold, (1 Kin. 22:14; 2 Chr. 18:13) I could not go beyond the word of the LORD my God, to do less or more.
Now therefore, please, you also (Num. 22:8) stay here tonight, that I may know what more the LORD will say to me.”

(Num. 22:9) And God came to Balaam at night and said to him, “If the men come to call you, rise and go with them; but (Num. 22:35; 23:5, 12, 16, 26; 24:13) only the word which I speak to you—that you shall do.”
So Balaam rose in the morning, saddled his donkey, and went with the princes of Moab.

(Balaam, the Donkey, and the Angel) Then God’s anger was aroused because he went, (Ex. 4:24) and the Angel of the LORD took His stand in the way as an adversary against him. And he was riding on his donkey, and his two servants were with him.

Now (Josh. 5:13; 2 Kin. 6:17; Dan. 10:7; Acts 22:9) the donkey saw the Angel of the LORD standing in the way with His drawn sword in His hand, and the donkey turned aside out of the way and went into the field. So Balaam struck the donkey to turn her back onto the road.
Then the Angel of the LORD stood in a narrow path between the vineyards, with a wall on this side and a wall on that side.
And when the donkey saw the Angel of the LORD, she pushed herself against the wall and crushed Balaam’s foot against the wall; so he struck her again.
Then the Angel of the LORD went further, and stood in a narrow place where there was no way to turn either to the right hand or to the left.
And when the donkey saw the Angel of the LORD, she lay down under Balaam; so Balaam’s anger was aroused, and he struck the donkey with his staff.
